All the laws will be made with one aim-- the protection of Southern people and property.
Its Administration will no longer be the elect of slaveholders and Abolitionists together, leaning to one side, afraid of the other;--but, chosen by one people, he will be bound to use every tittle of power in his hands for their sole safety.
The army and navy, the police and the courts, will then work but one way, and all the protection that earthly power can afford will then be surely given to the negro and his master.
The Virginian planter would be wise to wait.
Nothing can hurt him here but the conquest of the country; and before that is done there must be,
"Many a banner soiled and torn, And many a knight to earth be borne."

div4.p: On Thursday morning, at half-past 11 o'clock, Sarah V., wife of E. G. Hooker, and daughter of Wm. Beal, in the 26th year of her age.

Her funeral will take place this (Friday) evening, at 4 o'clock, from the residence of her husband, on 4th street, Navy Hill.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.

On Thursday evening, at 3 o'clock, at the residence of Mrs. Tyler, on 20th street, George W. Oast.
Jr., in the 23d year of his age.
His friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from Trinity Church, (Rev. Mr. Brown,) this afternoon, at 3 ½ o'clock.
Portsmouth papers please copy.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: To the memory of Mary Lumpkin, infant daughter of S. B. and Mary A. Wells, these lines are affectionately inscribed:

lg.l: God looked among his cherub band
And one was wanting there,
To swell along the holy band
The hymns of praise and prayer.
One little soul, which long had been
Half way 'tween earth and sky,
Untempted in a world of sin,
He watched with loving eye.
It was too promising a flower
To bloom upon this earth;
And God did give it angel power
And bright celestial birth.
The world was all too bleak and cold
To yield it quiet rest;
God took it to a shepherd's fold
And laid it on His breast.
Now Mary's in her Saviour's arms--
Forever undefiled;
Amid the little cherub band,
There little Mary lies.

div3.head: Now is the day and now the hour
div3.p:
--notice to all whom it may Concern.--A Secession Flag will be raised to-day, the 8th instant, Ano Domini 1861, for the purpose of showing that Creek Nation, in one solid phalanx, intend to secede, and leave that contaminated.
Hall out of the question; for we believe they have the hardness of heart of Pharaoh of old, and unless there is blood rained on them, we, the people, will still have to bear the yoke of oppression Old Massa Abe and his Cabinet have marked out for our destiny.
At 2 ½ o'clock P. M. we expect the true and loyal sons of the South to be present and address us.

div3.head: Superintendent of the city Gas Works
div3.p: --I respectfully announce myself as a candidate for re-election to the office of Superintendent of the city Gas Works.
Hon. Wm. C. Rives, by invitation, will address the citizens of Richmond, at the African Church, at 8 o'clock Tonight.

div3.head: Aid to the Volunteers of Henrico.
div3.p: --A meeting of the Committee to raise funds for aiding the Volunteers of the 33d Regiment, is earnestly requested at the county Court-House of Henrico, on Tuesday, 12th inst., at 12 o'clock M.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 56, page 3.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
We are getting the long-looked-for Inaugural in homŒpathic doses here, and we may exclaim, as I heard a physician of your city once, "If one-sixtieth part of a grain cures the chills, what would twenty grains do?"--A great crowd was assembled in the Courier and Mercury offices this evening, and one of the clerks was appointed to read what had come in, which was about half a column.
All listened with profound attention till the reader got through, which ended at that part where the Rail-splitter didn't want to shed blood, when one "irrepressible." pent up, thorough going haw-haw-haw went up with as great a gusto as if a veritable clown was performing tricks before us. His twaddle about the Union, the laws, and all that, we regard just as much as if a cur was to sit on his tail and bark at us.

Messrs. Editors, do you, or the people of Virginia, really understand who the people composing this Southern Confederacy are?--Have you or your people fully understood us and our characters?
I am sure you have not, nor can you do so without being with us. --Certainly many of your members of the Convention don't know us — especially your Rockbridgers and Augustans.
Would you not think it a very futile task for a parcel of sensible men to get together and bid the sun to stand still, or go back?
Just as possible for that sun to obey the presumptuous set, as to expect that this glorious Confederacy will give back one inch.

Well, we got the whole of the Inaugural tonight, by 10 o'clock, and it is read, and upon my word it is about as much cared for here as if he had told us that this is the year of our Lord, 1861.
Some of the people look on it as warlike, some see peace in it, but much the larger number see nothing in it, for it is neither fish, flesh, or fowl.
Firm to the instincts of that miserable party, spawned into existence by fanaticism and a deadly hatred to men whom they have all along regarded, and still regard, as their superiors, Mr. Lincoln is mysterious, without frankness, and strictly noncommittal, and leaves a wide berth to creep out of any unpleasant fix he may get himself in. If he really means war, the people here, with one accord and one voice, fling defiance, contempt and insult into his very teeth, and in that of all Black Republicans, North or South.

Now mark my prediction, that if Lincoln dare attempt what he darkly hints at, coercion, that in less than six months you will see a Southern army invading the North under the lead of President Davis in person.
I say "my prediction," it is not prediction, and I now tell you what I know, that it will be done, and Virginians--yes, Virginians, resident in your own State, will be in the scrummage.
Do you doubt it?
if you do, you need not doubt any more.
Look at President Davis' Inaugural again, and all men who know Davis, knows he never speaks words without meaning.
Seward, if no one else, understands him, for he has stripped him many a time of his hellish masks and held him up in his naked deformity to the world.
Yes, Seward knows Davis.
This war is a game that takes two to play at, and when once commenced it will not be ended on Southern soil.
The people here are just as cool and as dispassionate to- day as if Lincoln had never lived.
We are prepared for the most, and the worst, and we now say, "lay on Macduff."
Our harbor is filled with vessels, and we notice a large number of vessels "up, cleared, and sailed," for this port.

I will state a fact that may put to blush office-seekers who may see it: There has been but two postmasters in the city of Charleston since the days of Washington.
General Washington appointed Mr. Balot in1797, who served until his death, when the present incumbent, Mr. Huger, (pronounced Uger,) was appointed by Mr. Monroe. Mr. Huger is now over seventy years--of Huguenot blood — a gentleman of commanding and venerable appearance; about six feet high, well proportioned, fine Roman face, full head of hair, and as white as snow, fine black eye, heavy eyebrows, very erect, and one of the most high-toned gentlemen in all our city.--One peculiar trait he has, and that is he is remarkably fond of the company of young persons; and whilst they show great deference to him, no one, however young, is at all cramped in his society.
In many respects he greatly resembles the late Gov. Barbour, of your State.

We have never had at this port but four Collectors of the Customs since the formation of the United States, and one of these Collectors died soon after being appointed; so, you see, that Carolinians do not show the same fondness for the Government teat as is the wont of many of your United States.

Now, Messrs. Editors, as you are the peculiar friends of Mr. President Lincoln, I beg that you will just let him know that we are looking out for his arrival here, and that of his Lieut. General.
Ask them do come down; and, if not soon, to put it off till about August, when our friend, "Yellow Jack," will give them a hearty embrace.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch
Nearly and Accident — trial of a Criminal--
Weather.
div3.p:
On Sunday last two precocious juveniles, 12 to 13 years old, sons of Mr. John Hedrick, near Dayton, in this county, came very near being drowned.
They procured a store-box, and stuffing the cracks with paper, "launched their frail bark" upon a large pond.
They were sailing gaily when the craft capsized, and it was with difficulty they were saved from drowning, as the pond was quite deep.

Jno Landes, who was arrested some time since for pilfering small articles, was brought up for examination yesterday and remanded for further trial.
Landes is a rather curious character.
He has for some time been the terror of country dames, who scarcely allowed their bread, pies, cakes, &c., to cool before locking them up for fear Landes would be about, as was his custom.
He not only stole eatables, but "picked up" all light articles, such as watches, jewelry, &c. Sometimes a bag of wheat, some corn or meal, oats, a little bacon, chickens, taking but small quantities at a time, were carried off by him. He would have been tried before this, but immediately before his capture, whilst laying in wait out of doors, watching an opportunity to steal, he froze his toes, and taking a severe cold, contracted diphtheria, and has been under medical treatment since his incarceration; and yesterday was the first day which it was deemed proper for him to go out to be tried.
He will, no doubt, become a resident of the western part of Richmond.

Friday, Saturday and Sunday were three beautiful days, but since that it has been terrible.
Last night appeared to be as cold as any since December; but I presume cold strikes us harder after a few warm days.

The Inaugural of Abraham Lincoln comes upon our Union friends in this locality in rather a bad shape, as they confidently expected he would not preach coercion.
But they were mistaken, and, as a consequence, Union stock has a downward tendency.
Our papers will speak rather stronger for secession this week than at any other time since the election.
Taking that as an index to the sentiments of our people, you will perceive a very decided change in feeling in this county, and should not fear the result of a canvass upon the subject of secession us. Union.
Old Abe's"official" document will settle the question in Virginia.
Our Convention now stand committed to secession, (an honorable adjustment having failed,) and now let them act.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
affairs in Lynchburg.
div3.p:
As I advised you by telegraph last evening, a petition was put in circulation here yesterday, by the immediate supporters of Messrs. Speed and Slaughter, our delegates to the Convention, instructing them to vote for an ordinance of secession immediately.
Long before night it was numerously signed by them, and would have received any number of signatures from other parties but for the fact that it was regarded in the light of instruction. and confined only to the immediate supporters of these gentlemen.
It is needless to state that this great revolution in feeling was caused by the coercive course of policy laid down by the leader of the Satanic imps who disgrace the city named in honor of the immortal Washington.

The signs of the times in some other respects indicate that we are rushing rapidly towards secession.
Action was taken Tuesday last, in Pendleton Division, Sons of Temperance, of this city, which is one of the largest and most influential Divisions in the State, tending towards secession from the National Division.
This action was caused from the fact of negroes being initiated and fellow-shipped, and elected to office in the Yankee States.
Some of the applicants who are getting up petitions to be forwarded to Mars Abe, begin to have rather an up-hill business of it since he has showed his colors.
Mr. Jacob Pettet, of Baltimore, a worthy young man, connected with the Adams Express Company, died quite suddenly from pneumonia, in Petersburg, Virginia, on last Monday night.

div3.head: Blue birds, ice, and crocuses.
div3.p:
--Blue birds made their appearance this week, and on Wednesday turtles were singing in the swamps.
On the same day we noticed crocuses above ground in a warm spot, though not in bloom.
At the same time the ice at Lake Wenham was a foot or more in thickness. --Salem (Mass.) Observer.
In Washington, Wednesday, the Vermont delegation called on Gen. Scott and Messrs. Seward, Dix and Bates. Gen. Scott made a speech in which he thanked Vermont for her Presidential vote in 1852.

div2.head:
Telegraphic News.
reported for the Richmond Dispatch.

div3.head: Extra session of the U. S. Senate.
div3.p:
--Mr. Wigfall, the resolution to print the Inaugural being up, argued that its policy was war. He said the representatives from the Confederate States were accredited to this Government to make a treaty for a peaceable separation and division of the public property and debt.
It was nonsense to talk, as Lincoln did, of an unbroken Union, when seven States were out, never more to return.
If this Government does not remove the troops at Forts Sumter and Pickens, the Confederate States will soon do it for it. The old Union is dead, and the only question is, shall it be buried in a respectable Protestant manner, or by an Irish wake?

Mr. Douglas, in rejoinder, reiterated his positions of yesterday, that the Inaugural was indicative of peace.
He learned, from the best military authority, it would take 10,000 men, and the entire navy, to reinforce Sumter.

Mr. Mason said it was unusual to print an inaugural, as it was not a Senate document, but merely a disquisition on political views.
He took issue with Mr. Douglas, arguing that it was plainly a proclamation of war, only omitting the time when the military forces were to be used for the purposes stated therein.
There was a wicked omission, too, of the fact, that the Union was broken.
As for Virginia, he could not say whether she would take common cause with her sister States against coercion.
Adjourned.

div3.head: Municipal elections at the North.
div3.p: --The towns of Hamilton, Madison, Eaton, Georgetown, and Brookfield, in Madison county, each elect Republican Supervisors.

Oswego,N. Y.,March 6.-- At the charter election to-day, Hon. Henry Fitzhugh, Republican, was elected Mayor by 351 majority.
All the Republican and city ward officers were elected, except the Overseer for the Poor.--The majorities show a Republican gain since last fall.

Auburn,N. Y.,March 6.-- The charter election in this city yesterday, resulted in the success of the entire Republican city ticket.--George Humphreys, Republican candidate for Mayor, has a majority of 508.
This is the largest Republican majority ever given in Auburn.

Lockport,N. Y.,March 6. --The charter election, which took place in this village yesterday, resulted in the election of the entire Republican ticket.
Republican Trustees were elected by an average majority of 120.
Utiga,N. Y.,March 6.--In this county, Oneida, thirteen Democratic and thirteen Republican Supervisors were elected.

Norwich, N. Y.,March 6.-- Chenango co.--The towns of Norwich, McDonough, and Smithville, elect the Democratic ticket, and the towns of Oxford, Preston, Guilford, and Sherburne, elect the Republican ticket.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
--The War Department has received despatches from Maj.Anderson, dated the 4th of March, in which he reports that his mail and market facilities continued.
There is good feeling between his officers and the Carolinians.

Secretary Cameron has gone to Pennsylvania for a few days.
Ex-Secretary Holt remains in office until his return.
The new Cabinet held its first meeting to-day.
Passed Assistant Surgeon Carrington, U. S. N., of Virginia, has resigned.
The Diplomatic corps paid their respects to the President.
No nominations by the President were sent to the Senate to-day.

div3.head: The Southern Congress.
div3.p: --Mr. Clayton reported a bill providing, in the event of a conflict or refusal of the United States to recognize the independence of the Southern Confederacy, no courts of the Confederate States shall have cognizance of civil cases for the citizens of the United States, and all civil cases pending shall be dismissed.
A resolution was adopted authorizing the President to instruct the Commissioners to the European courts to enter into a treaty for the extension of the international copy-right privilege.
Mr. Braxton Bragg was confirmed Brigadier General; also, Wm.J. Hardee, as Colonel of the First Infantry.

div3.head: Ovation to Gen. Twiggs.
div3.p:
--The reception of Gen. Twiggs was most enthusiastic — a universal demonstration by the citizens and military and members of the Convention, who united in a procession.
In reply to the welcome, Gen. Twiggs said he hoped Providence would grant him sufficient strength to take part in the momentous struggle which threatens the country.

div3.head: Later from Europe.
div3.p: --The steamer Bremen, for mSouthampton on the 20th, has arrived.
Commercial.

Liverpool,March 7.--Cotton dull, but not lower.
Consols 91¼@91Ȃ.

div3.head: Large fire.
div3.p:
--A fire at Dundee, Thursday, destroyed thirty-five houses, a church, two hotels, and all the stores but one.
Loss, $100,000.

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p:
--Cotton firm — Uplands middling 11½.
Flour firm — Sou $5.25@5.60.--Wheat quiet.
Corn firmer--M 57@60 Pork heavy — Mess $17@17.12; Prime unchanged.
Lard firm at 9½@10¼. Whiskey quiet at 16½ Sugar steady — Orleans 5@5Ȃ ; Muscovado 4 @5½.
Coffee steady at 11½@13½.
Spirits Turpentine dull at 36½.
Stocks firm — N. Y. Centrals 77½ ; Mo.6's 65.

Baltimore,March 7.--Flour lower-- Howard street and Ohio $5.25; City Mills $5. Wheat steady — Red $1.25@1.40, on Change; White $1.40@1.60.
Corn steady — Mixed 55@57; Yellow 59@1 cts.; White 63@64 Provisions steady and unchanged.
Coffee firm at 12½@13 Whiskey 1 lower, and quoted at 19

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, about the first of last month, (February,) a negro man, named " Sam," the property ofBenj.
J. Williamson. He is about five feet six inches in height, of mulatto complexion, and has a good head of hair.
Said negro has been accustomed to working in a tobacco factory, and was hired last year by G. W. Gilliam, Esq., and is no doubt lurking about the city.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to us, in Richmond.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
div3.closer: Corner of Bank and 11th sts. mh 7--eod5t

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on Monday, March 4th, my negro man, Sandy, He is about 5½ feet high, stout built, 24 or 25 years old, a brown color.
He has a wife at Mr. Toney Ford's, in Henrico.
He was hired last year by B. W. Green, from P. M Tabb & Son. I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, or in some jail in the city.
div3.closer:
Chas. G. Paleske,
Henrico county. mh 7--2t*

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway from the subscriber, about the middle of January, my Man "Manuel. " Said negro is about five feet ten inches in height, bushy head of hair, and a very dark mulatto, and has a slight impediment in his speech when spoken to. Said negro is believed to be lurking about Atlee's Station, in Hanover county, or about Richmond.--The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond, or Hanover Jail, or to D. R. Jones, in King William co., Va.
div3.closer:
Thos. Doswell,
Junction P O., Hanover co., Va. mh 1--1m

div3.head: Grays, attention
div3.p: --Members desirous of disposing of their old Uniform Coats, are requested to leave them, with their names attached, with Sergeant Wm. Ira Smith immediately.
div3.closer:
By order.
R. W. Beanch, 1st Serg't. fe 25--ts

div3.head:
By Hector Davis, Auct'r.
Trustee's Sale of Valuable slaves at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Trustee in a deed of trust; dated December 13th; 1860, and recorded in the Clerk's Office of the Husting Court of the city of Richmond, and at the request of creditors secured in said deed, I shall proceed to sell, at the Auction Rooms of Hector Davis, in the city of Richmond, at the hour of 10 o'clock, on Monday, the 18th day of March, 1861, six valuable slaves consist of four Men, who are all young and active, one Boy about 16 years of age, and a valuable Woman.
Terms.--Cash
